descriptions: GitHub page (in construction): documentation for the project and guidelines on how to contribute
Open-source repository with standardized wearable data schemas and tools (in construction)

GitHub repository for MEDWEAR standard (to be launched) - will include schemas, ROS2 messages, conversion libraries, and documentation. MEDWEAR: an open-source Python library for real-time transformation of high-frequency wearable sensor data into formats usable by robotics systems such as ROS 2
ROS4HC: ROS4healthcare message definitions for various biosignal data types (including BCG)
MEDWEAR standard for medical wearable devices - extending Open mHealth with raw sensor data schemas

MEDWEAR: a unified data standard/schema for raw wearable sensor streams, supporting high-frequency data and interoperability across digital health platforms with structured schemas for signals such as BCG, ECG, EEG, PPG, etc.
"Toward the Next Standard for Medical Wearables in Switzerland" symposium, May 6, 2025, ETH Zurich (31 participants)

Workshops involving stakeholders to identify emergent requirement categories for digital health integration (e.g., Multi-Modal Data Synchronization, Real-Time Processing, Cross-Vendor Interoperability, Clinical Workflow Integration, Implementation Support)
Pre-symposium e-survey on wearable standardization needs
Symposium breakout group materials and documentation
"MEDWEAR: Data Standardization of Wearable Devices for Healthcare Applications" - manuscript in preparation
“Embedding computational neurorehabilitation in clinical practice using a modular intelligent health system”
Symposium with panel discussion bringing together clinical, research, and industry stakeholders
Collaboration with SUPSI and UZH to write the paper “MEDWEAR: Data Standardization of Wearable Devices for Healthcare Applications”
Academic and clinical researchers: ~3,000–5,000 users (based on active publication trends and members of consortia such as Mobilise-D, SPHERE, SwissNeuroRehab, and related EU-funded initiatives)
Developers and engineers: ~1,000–2,000 users (based on GitHub activity and community size around Open mHealth, ROS 2 healthcare projects, and wearable SDKs)
Industry partners: ~500–1,000 users (based on partnership networks, including Leitwert, pharma biomarker teams, and wearable OEMs)

software_tools.reasoning: Combined two extracted sources. MEDWEAR library and repository description refer to the same core software (one tool, unique description merged). ROS4HC is a separate software output with its own description and URL. Count is 2. Kept all distinct descriptions. Used mean of confidence scores where applicable.

models_standards.reasoning: All extracted information refers to a single MEDWEAR standard for medical wearables. Both sources describe different facets of the same standard and both state a quantity of one. There are no other models, standards, or related outputs listed in the provided text, and no URLs. VERBATIM EXTRACTION from the provided structured data, with confidence values reported as found and averaged for quantity.

workshops.reasoning: Both source segments count one workshop and provide additive details. Aggregated the symposium specifics and the summary of workshop themes into the descriptions array, per combination rules. No URLs were present. VERBATIM EXTRACTION for event name; summary of discussions included as a distinct description.

config.system_prompt:
EXTRACTION STRATEGY:
  1. PRIMARY: Look for data in the specified location/table/section
  2. FALLBACK: If not found, search broader document context for semantically equivalent information
  3. FLEXIBILITY: Allow for format variations, OCR errors, and synonym usage

  LOCATION FLEXIBILITY:
  - Handle table format variations (column/row order, spacing, naming)
  - Consider synonyms and equivalent terms
  - Account for OCR/parsing errors that may affect document quality

  QUALITY STANDARDS:
  - Extract actual values found in the document
  - If uncertain, provide best interpretation with appropriate confidence
  - Only return null if the information category truly doesn't exist
  - Convert abbreviated amounts (k=1000) to full numbers where applicable
  

  REPORT OUTPUT FOCUS:
  - 15 standard output categories in "List of Outputs" table
  - Each category: quantity number, descriptions list, URLs list
  - Separate descriptions from URLs even when mixed in same cell
  - Academic collaborations vs Industrial partnerships (distinct categories)
  - Preserve all detailed descriptions and web addresses
